title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main goal in the presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: To encourage the audience to think about New York City as a place for technological innovation.

options.label: B
options.text: To encourage the audience to think about New York City as a home to native wildlife that are subject to a grand evolutionary experiment.

options.label: C
options.text: To discuss the importance of urban planning in New York City.

options.label: D
options.text: To talk about the history of New York City.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the northern dusky salamanders in the presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: They are an example of a species that has become extinct in New York City.

options.label: B
options.text: They are an example of a species that has adapted to the urban environment in New York City.

options.label: C
options.text: They are an example of a species that is found only in the Bronx.

options.label: D
options.text: They are an example of a species that has been affected by the construction of bridges in New York City.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the camera traps set up by the speaker and his colleagues?

options.label: A
options.text: To capture images of coyotes in New York City.

options.label: B
options.text: To capture images of white-footed mice in New York City.

options.label: C
options.text: To capture images of northern dusky salamanders in New York City.

options.label: D
options.text: To capture images of all wildlife in New York City.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the genetic differences found in the white-footed mice in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: They indicate that the mice are adapting to the urban environment.

options.label: B
options.text: They indicate that the mice are becoming extinct in New York City.

options.label: C
options.text: They indicate that the mice are not affected by the urban environment.

options.label: D
options.text: They indicate that the mice are only found in certain parks in New York City.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of sequencing thousands of genes from the city mice and comparing them to thousands of genes from the country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the genetic differences between the two populations.

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the evolutionary history of the mice.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the impact of the urban environment on the mice.

options.label: D
options.text: To determine the genetic similarities between the two populations.

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

multiple-choice.question: What was Malcolm McLean's occupation when he first thought of the concept of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: Ship captain

options.label: B
options.text: Truck driver

options.label: C
options.text: Dockworker

options.label: D
options.text: Businessman

multiple-choice.question: What was the main problem that Malcolm McLean faced when delivering cotton bales to the pier in Hoboken, New Jersey?

options.label: A
options.text: He got lost on the way

options.label: B
options.text: He had to wait for a long time for the goods to be unloaded

options.label: C
options.text: He had to pay a high fee for the shipment

options.label: D
options.text: He had to deal with difficult dockworkers

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the traditional method of shipping non-bulk cargo that Malcolm McLean observed?

options.label: A
options.text: Containerization

options.label: B
options.text: Break bulk shipping

options.label: C
options.text: Bulk shipping

options.label: D
options.text: Freight shipping

multiple-choice.question: How long did it typically take to load and unload a ship using the break bulk shipping method?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-2 days

options.label: B
options.text: 1-2 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: 2-4 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: 8 days to load and 8 days to unload

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Malcolm McLean's first container ship?

options.label: A
options.text: The Container X

options.label: B
options.text: The Ideal X

options.label: C
options.text: The Malcolm McLean

options.label: D
options.text: The Global Trader

title: Poetic stickup: Put the financial aid in the bag - Carvens Lissaint

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary goal in this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: To rob the financial aid office

options.label: B
options.text: To protest the high cost of tuition

options.label: C
options.text: To obtain financial aid for education

options.label: D
options.text: To intimidate the financial aid staff

multiple-choice.question: The speaker references several famous rappers in their monologue. Which of the following rappers is NOT mentioned?

options.label: A
options.text: Tupac Shakur

options.label: B
options.text: The Notorious B.I.G.

options.label: C
options.text: KRS-One

options.label: D
options.text: Jay-Z

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the effect of the current financial aid system on students?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides them with sufficient funds to pursue their education

options.label: B
options.text: It forces them to take on debt and struggle financially

options.label: C
options.text: It gives them equal access to educational opportunities

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on their financial situation

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions the Thirteenth Amendment in their monologue. What is the significance of this reference?

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the speaker's opposition to the financial aid system

options.label: B
options.text: It draws a parallel between the financial aid system and historical systems of oppression

options.label: C
options.text: It emphasizes the importance of education in achieving freedom

options.label: D
options.text: It is a random reference with no significance to the context

multiple-choice.question: What is the tone of the speaker's monologue?

options.label: A
options.text: Calm and collected

options.label: B
options.text: Angry and confrontational

options.label: C
options.text: Sad and despairing

options.label: D
options.text: Sarcastic and humorous

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript regarding the use of words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Using complex vocabulary is essential for effective writing.

options.label: B
options.text: Bigger words are always better in writing.

options.label: C
options.text: Using simple and concise language is often more effective than using complex vocabulary.

options.label: D
options.text: Writers should always use a thesaurus to find more complicated words.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on using "10-dollar words" in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: They are essential for conveying complex ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: They are only useful for impressing the reader.

options.label: C
options.text: They are worthless if they're not understood by the audience.

options.label: D
options.text: They should be used as often as possible.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the key to effective writing in today's world?

options.label: A
options.text: Using complex vocabulary and lengthy descriptions.

options.label: B
options.text: Knowing your audience and being concise.

options.label: C
options.text: Writing at a fourth-grade reading level.

options.label: D
options.text: Using the same 50 words repeatedly.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice on using variety in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Variety is the most important aspect of writing.

options.label: B
options.text: Variety should be avoided in favor of brevity.

options.label: C
options.text: Variety is the spice of life, but brevity is its bread and butter.

options.label: D
options.text: Variety is only necessary for novelists.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for those who want to use complex vocabulary?

options.label: A
options.text: Use a thesaurus to find more complicated words.

options.label: B
options.text: Save your money and buy a Scrabble board.

options.label: C
options.text: Take a course on creative writing.

options.label: D
options.text: Read more books to improve your vocabulary.

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a partnership between two different species, such as bees and flowers, where both species depend on each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Mutualism

options.label: B
options.text: Symbiosis

options.label: C
options.text: Parasitism

options.label: D
options.text: Commensalism

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way Clark's nutcrackers store seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They store them in their nests

options.label: B
options.text: They store them in a pouch in their throat

options.label: C
options.text: They store them in holes in trees

options.label: D
options.text: They store them in underground burrows

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers remember where they have cached seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They use their sense of smell

options.label: B
options.text: They use landmarks on the landscape

options.label: C
options.text: They use a mental map

options.label: D
options.text: They don't remember, they just search randomly

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the symbiosis between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pines for the trees?

options.label: A
options.text: The birds provide nutrients to the trees

options.label: B
options.text: The birds help to disperse the trees' seeds

options.label: C
options.text: The birds protect the trees from pests

options.label: D
options.text: The birds provide shade for the trees

multiple-choice.question: How have whitebark pines evolved to suit their symbiosis with Clark's nutcrackers?

options.label: A
options.text: Their branches have become shorter and more dense

options.label: B
options.text: Their cones have become smaller and less accessible

options.label: C
options.text: Their branches all sweep upwards with the cones at the very ends

options.label: D
options.text: Their trunks have become thicker and more resilient

title: How many universes are there? - Chris Anderson

multiple-choice.question: How many Earths can fit inside the sun?

options.label: B
options.text: 1 million

options.label: C
options.text: 100 million

options.label: D
options.text: 1 billion

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many galaxies are detectable by our telescopes?

options.label: A
options.text: 100 million

options.label: B
options.text: 100 billion

options.label: C
options.text: 1 trillion

options.label: D
options.text: 10 trillion

multiple-choice.question: According to string theory, how many universes could exist in the multiverse?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 to the power of 100

options.label: B
options.text: 10 to the power of 500

options.label: C
options.text: 10 to the power of 1000

options.label: D
options.text: Infinity

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of the multiverse in physics?

options.label: A
options.text: A single universe with multiple dimensions

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple universes with different physical laws and properties

options.label: C
options.text: A universe with infinite space and time

options.label: D
options.text: A universe with a finite number of stars and galaxies

multiple-choice.question: According to some physicists, what is the nature of the space-time continuum?

options.label: A
options.text: Finite and bounded

options.label: B
options.text: Infinite and containing an infinite number of pocket universes

options.label: C
options.text: Expanding at a constant rate

options.label: D
options.text: Contracting at a constant rate

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

multiple-choice.question: What was the conversation between Richard Feynman and his dad that sparked Feynman's interest in science?

options.label: A
options.text: Feynman's dad explained the concept of inertia to him.

options.label: B
options.text: Feynman's dad asked him to solve a math problem.

options.label: C
options.text: Feynman's dad told him about the movement of subatomic particles.

options.label: D
options.text: Feynman's dad explained why the ball went to the back of the wagon, but also admitted that nobody really knows.

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with being the first person to accurately measure the circumference of the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Eratosthenes

options.label: B
options.text: Aristotle

options.label: C
options.text: Galileo

options.label: D
options.text: Richard Feynman

multiple-choice.question: What method did Eratosthenes use to calculate the circumference of the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: He measured the distance between two points on the Earth's surface and used the angle of the sun's shadow to calculate the circumference.

options.label: B
options.text: He used a stick stuck in the ground to measure the angle of the sun's shadow.

options.label: C
options.text: He measured the diameter of the Earth using a ruler.

options.label: D
options.text: He used a complex mathematical formula to calculate the circumference.

multiple-choice.question: Who was the experimental physicist who refined and confirmed other people's results, and was able to calculate the speed of light to within two percent of its actual value?

options.label: A
options.text: Galileo

options.label: B
options.text: Eratosthenes

options.label: C
options.text: Armand Fizeau

options.label: D
options.text: Richard Feynman

multiple-choice.question: What was the key piece of equipment that Armand Fizeau used to calculate the speed of light?

options.label: A
options.text: A toothed wheel

options.label: B
options.text: A lamp

options.label: C
options.text: A mirror

options.label: D
options.text: A ruler
